headline: Fareed Zakaria GPS
subHeadline: America's Mess With Mexico. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: FAREED ZAKARIA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: On May 13, 1846, the United States declared war on Mexico. President James Polk claimed that America had been attacked. But in reality, the invasion was a brazen land grant. American troops made it all the way to Mexico City, and the US annexed much of today's western United States. The future founder of the Republican Party, and Illinois Congressman named Abraham Lincoln passionately opposed the war.But today's Republicans have Mexico in their sights once again. Back when he was president, Donald Trump asked Defense Secretary Mark Esper if he could launch missiles at Mexico's drug cartels without Mexico's permission, and then blamed the attack on another country. We could do it quietly, Trump said, no one would know it was us. Esper told him the idea was ridiculous, an act of war against one of America's biggest trading partners. But Trump would not back down, and an Oval Office fantasy -- DONALD TRUMP (R), FORMER US PRESIDENT AND PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I will deploy all necessary military assets --

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- became a 2024 campaign pledge.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Justified military force to decimate the cartel.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: He told the Mexican president either you do it or we do it.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And soon it was a popular Republican policy. Over 20 Republican congressmen have signed on to a vast war power authorization --GEORGE W. BUSH, FORMER US PRESIDENT: On my orders.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The DEA says Guzman was responsible for 25 percent of all the narcotics flowing into the US.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: El Chapo built a sophisticated billion dollar multinational empire that rival Fortune 500 companies.SHANNON O'NEIL, AUTHOR, "GLOBALIZATION MYTH": He was apprehended a few times, and got away a couple of times, but now is in the US criminal system and doesn't look to get out anytime soon.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: El Chapo bequeathed his vast empire to four of his sons, the Sinaloa Cartel and list of heavily armed fighting force known as the Little Chapos or Los Chapitos.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Ivan, Alfredo, Ovidio and Joaquin.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And it was El Chapo sons who made a prescient early bet on a promising new product, and would become America's biggest suppliers of fentanyl.

utterances.speaker: ANABEL HERNANDEZ, INVESTIGATIVE JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: They were able to see that producing fentanyl will be the new very important synthetic drug in the market.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Americans had been hooked on prescription opioids like OxyContin in the '90s.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Doctors are prescribing more and more Percocet, Vicodin, OxyContin, and we can't seem to stop taking it.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But then the government cracked down on big pharma in the 2000s. The crackdown left a massive void in the opioid market and Los Chapitos' race to fill it. First with heroin, then with fentanyl, the profits from their new product were off the charts.

utterances.speaker: HERNANDEZ
utterances.sentences: The bosses of the Sinaloa cartel are able to get just for themselves $400 million per month, just profits in the pocket. ZAKARIA

utterances.speaker: HERNANDEZ
utterances.sentences: It's very easy and very cheap. You don't need all that infrastructure.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: By 2017, fentanyl was causing more overdoses than any other drug in America. Meanwhile, in Mexico, a new president, Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador was embracing a new approach to the drug war.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He's even popularized the saying, "abrazos no balazos."

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Hugs not bullets. After years of Mexico's military fighting the cartels, Mexico's people had paid a horrifying price. Ten of thousands were dead from drug-related violence. AMLO wanted to reduce that violence and boost the job market. He dismantled much of Mexico's years long security collaboration with America.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is what it sounds like, a drug cartel powers the state.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But when Mexican forces tried to capture one of Los Chapitos --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: They're outgunning law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Doesn't even look like it was close to being a fair fight.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: They were no match for the cartels armory.O'NEIL: The next Mexican military captured them and then they got away.

utterances.speaker: HERNANDEZ
utterances.sentences: Los Chapitos are powerful and strong but not by themselves. They have the complicity of many parts of the Mexican government.

utterances.speaker: HERNANDEZ
utterances.sentences: You have to kill all the civilians that live in Culiacan.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The United States would be at war with its biggest trading partner, and migration already setting records would spike even more.

utterances.speaker: HERNANDEZ
utterances.sentences: It's ridiculous that you are thinking that, oh, let's bomb the cartels.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: If America really wants to hit the cartels where it hurts, it should tackle its own insatiable demand for their product. Roughly 80 percent of the world's opioids are consumed in the United States of America.

utterances.speaker: HERNANDEZ
utterances.sentences: If you really want to fight against the cartels, destroy the market.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But rather than attacking the demand problem, America has relied on brute force to fight drug cartels --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The DEA says it has trained 551 Mexican police officers.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- in a decade's long losing game of whack-a-mole.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Seventy percent of all the cocaine seized in the United States came from here.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In the 1980s, Miami was America's capital of cocaine.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The largest bust in United States history.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: One billion dollars worth of cocaine.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The DEA launched Operation Swordfish, indicting dozens in the drug trade. But the cocaine kept on coming.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Operation just called, US troops fanned out in the air and on the ground.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In 1989 --GEORGE H. W. BUSH, FORMER US PRESIDENT: the goals of the United States have been to combat drug trafficking.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: President George H. W. Bush invaded Panama, to take out its leader drug trafficker, Manuel Noriega.

utterances.speaker: BUSH
utterances.sentences: I think it's a major victory against the drug lords.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But American demand was still going through the roof. In the late 1990s --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We are proud to stand with our friend and our neighbor.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- President Bill Clinton launched Plan Colombia.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is a war and the enemy is cocaine.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- sending billions to that country's military, target its cocaine operations. Drug production did slow down, but then came back even bigger. And the production decline in Colombia led to Mexico's cartels filling the vacuum.O'NEIL: We've seen this over and over again, if you destroy one laboratory, you destroy one field, you destroy one network, others will come and replace that.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And there's another way that America actually helps Mexico's cartels besides its appetite for their product. Seventy to 90 percent of all the guns trafficked in Mexico come from the United States.O'NEIL: It is the case that the Mexican government has long claimed against the United States. You want us to stop sending drugs, well, you need to stop sending the guns that feel the violence here.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: a breaking point at the US-Mexico border.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Year after year, records of the border are shattered.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: A major surge of border crossings.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Over 2.4 million migrants were apprehended last year, an all time high --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Those numbers have been staggering.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- breaking the record set just one year earlier, which topped the record set the year before that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We are at the point of no turn.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: People have been coming --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Everywhere from Haiti, to Venezuela --

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- from all over the world.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: India, Vietnam, Afghanistan.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But one country that's actually not driving the surge is Mexico. At the start of the century, Mexicans made up 98 percent of the migrants at the southern border. Last year, only 29 percent were from Mexico. What's more, the number of Mexicans coming to America has sometimes been fewer than the number of Mexicans leaving the US to go back to Mexico in recent years. That's due in part to the country's economy, which has been doing pretty well.

utterances.speaker: PETER GOODMAN, REPORTER, NEW YORK TIMES
utterances.sentences: People want to stay home. And the more working opportunities there are in Mexico, the more people will tend to stay home or even return.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Mexico has even become a destination for many migrants, the fifth most popular country for asylum seekers in the world in 2022. Instead of being big border crossers, the Mexicans have become America's go to border in forces, sadly.JONATHAN BLITZER, AUTHOR, "EVERYONE WHO IS GONE IS HERE": One element of an American response is always going to be to outsource as much of the enforcement question as it can to the Mexican government.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Mexico is actually in very much the same bind with migration as America.O'NEIL: Mexico has a very similar problem, overwhelmed with people who are applying for asylum. Police forces are overwhelmed, the shelters are totally overwhelmed.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And as Mexico's government struggles to keep up, the journey has become even more perilous for the migrants.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: What makes it so dangerous is the fact that there are threats really on all sides.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: On the one side, violent drug cartels who have found a cruel new way to make money,O'NEIL: You see organized crime moving increasingly into the trafficking of migrants.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The smuggling business has become even more lucrative than dealing fentanyl. For migrants, it can be just as deadly.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: When cartels can't extort migrants for money, they often just kill the people that kidnapped.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Another danger, often Mexican authorities, sometimes corrupt, sometimes inept, sometimes lethal. In March 2023, a fire broke out at a migrant detention center --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Migrants were left locked in the cells.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: There's no question that the US is certainly complicit in some of the things that are happening in Mexico, if not outright responsible. ZAKARIAJuly 2014, America was witnessing an unprecedented crisis.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: They came without their parents.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A wave of migrant children coming from Central America.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: Seemingly overnight, tens of thousands of children and family showed up at the southern border, the US government was caught completely flat-footed.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: President Obama pushed Mexico to focus on the southern border, Mexico southern border. One thousand miles away, US dollars helped transform Mexico's border with Guatemala. A network of military bases, observation towers, canine teams and mobile checkpoints sprung up on the hunt for migrants.

utterances.speaker: BARACK OBAMA, FORMER US PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: UNIDENTIFIED MALE

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The next year, Mexico deported more Central Americans than the United States for the first time in history.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: And so by the end of the Obama administration, you weren't seeing the same kind of drama at the southern border that you saw in 2014. People kind of wrote it off as problem solved.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But Obama strategy didn't work for long, President Trump arrived with bold rhetoric.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We're not letting these people invade our country.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But when his draconian policies failed --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The growing outrage over families being separated at the border --

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- and the construction of his border wall dragged, Trump focused on turning Mexico into his wall. Many believed that would be a challenge. Mexico's new leader, Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, had campaigned on ending his country's migrant crackdown.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: This idea that we're not going to do America's dirty work.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But as a fresh wave of migrants headed for the US --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We want all of them to stop. We want Mexico to stop.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Trump threatened to bury Mexico's economy under an avalanche of tariffs, AMLO changed his tune on migration.O'NEIL: Once he came into office, he doubled down and moved even further than the previous government.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: He expanded Trump's Remain in Mexico policy --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Forced to wait in some of the most dangerous cities on earth.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- trapping more migrants in Mexico. And he turned his newly formed National Guard meant for taking on drug violence into a border patrol.UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE (through translation): Please don't let me be taken back.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Thousands of troops fanned out across Mexico.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: And there were scenes, really grisly scenes, all through Mexico of these National Guardsmen really cracking down and responding with force.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Migrants would tear gas, beaten and thrown into prison like detention centers. Some were shot and killed. The Mexican government has defended the National Guard, saying it respects human rights.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Mexico is doing more for the United States as of now, than Congress.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: President Biden took office promising to dramatically change the nation's approach to migration.JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENT OF UNITED STATES: It's time for our better angels to prevail.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But the US continued to rely on Mexico to do its dirty work.O'NEIL: Cooperation on migration continued and even expanded with the Biden administration.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The results under Biden more of the same.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: Let's get real. In the same way that water runs downhill, human beings go where there's a better deal.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And that better deal more economic opportunity and a better life continues to be found in the United States. The truth is, Mexico can't solve America's border crisis. It's really up to America.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: All of the obvious solutions to reduce pressure at the southern border run through Congress, and Congress is a kind of dead zone on this issue --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Lawmakers block a border deal.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: -- until we run right into a wall.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Mass protests --UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKERS (in unison): Four more years. Four more years.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- against alleged election fraud demands for a recount.UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKERS (in unison): Stop the steal. Stop the steal.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A politician insisting he won the presidency weeks after officials called the election for his opponent.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: This was a landslide.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A familiar story for American voters, and as it turns out, for Mexican voters too.ANDRES MANUEL LOPEZ OBRADOR, MEXICAN PRESIDENT (through translation): We're going to ask that the elections be cleaned.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: After two months of public debate, accusations and protests in the streets, a winner has finally been declared in Mexico's presidential election.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The year was 2006, and the election's loser, the man sewing the chaos, was the former Mexico City Mayor Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador. AMLO, as he's come to be known, would never forget that loss. And for that, Mexico's democracy would suffer.In 2018, AMLO won the presidency, and increasingly adopted Donald Trump's waves, accused of defying the Constitution and threatening Mexico's democracy. His handpicked successor, Claudia Sheinbaum, was recently elected president. Many fear that AMLO will still be the power behind the throne once she takes office.

utterances.speaker: HERNANDEZ
utterances.sentences: In his head, he's not the president of Mexico, he's the owner of Mexico.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Mexico is rapidly becoming an illiberal democracy, like Hungary or Turkey, but in this case right on America's doorstep. The birth of Mexico's modern democracy is an inspiring and relatively recent tale. The country was a one party state for over seven decades, ruled by the Institutional Revolutionary Party or PRI.O'NEIL: They held elections, but not free and fair elections. So they managed to control the presidency, the federal government as well as the governorships and others for many, many years.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Every leader chose his successor, and the party was accused of relying on repression and fraud to ensure victory. But then, along came a small but mighty government watchdog, the Federal Electoral Institute. It oversaw Mexico's elections, and became the foundation of Mexico's democracy.O'NEIL: This electoral Institute really became world class. It became one of the most independent run by technically sophisticated people, and became known as a model of electoral agencies.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In 2000, the PRI's grip on power finally ended with then president Ernesto Zedillo, paving the way for Mexico's first free and fair election. But AMLO was just around the corner. After he lost the presidency for the first time in 2006.LOPEZ OBRADOR (through translation): We will continue to fight.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: He ran and lost again in 2012. Through it all, he kept his eyes on the prize.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: In a few hours, Mexicans will be waking up to Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador as the newly elected president.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In an effort to undercut the institute, AMLO has again and again championed what he calls electoral reform. In late 2022, he proposed massive cuts to the institute's budget and personnel, potentially crippling its capacity to run elections. Democracy, as Mexico knew it, hung in the balance. Even so, Mexico's legislature approved AMLO's reforms.Protesters took to the streets. But then Mexico Supreme Court overturned the president's plan, saving Mexican democracy for now. O'NEIL: He has systematically eroded the checks and balances that civil society leaders and politicians worked hard to build up over the last 20 years.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Taking a page out of Donald Trump's playbook, Lopez Obrador has repeatedly vilified members of the media.(FOREIGN LANGUAGE)

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: At one press conference, he named several prominent journalists saying that listening to them is "bad for your health," and that, "you could even develop a brain tumor." The very next day, there was an assassination attempt against one of those journalists, prominent news anchor Ciro Gomez Leyva.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: Mexico, I think, is probably one of the most dangerous countries in which to be a journalist in the world. And it doesn't seem like the government is even coming close to taking the situation seriously enough.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Another frightening feature of AMLO's Mexico, a chilling surveillance tool called Pegasus. Operators can covertly install the powerful software on a target cell phone, and then see nearly everything on that device from texts to emails, to photos. Mexico's military was the first ever client to purchase the spyware over a decade ago. And over the years, Mexico has been one of the most prolific users of the software in the world.The company that developed Pegasus says that its software is supposed to be used only for fighting crime and terrorists. AMLO promised to end the political spying, but Pegasus infections targeting journalists and activists have continued under his watch. Many suspect the military is responsible, they deny it. And the military's powers under AMLO, hardly and (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: HERNANDEZ
utterances.sentences: The military became with AMLO, the main power in Mexico and this is very, very, very dangerous.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: AMLO and his Morena majority legislature replaced the federal police with a new National Guard full of active military members. Mexico's Armed Forces have also headed up customs operations and built major infrastructure projects like a controversial new airport.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: To see the degree to which the military is now kind of out and about in the domestic sphere, I think that's a major shift and something that given Mexico's history, a lot of people are legitimately concerned about it.O'NEIL: Democracies are really hard to build and they're easy to break. I think the real question is what does the next government do?

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: It's a hugely significant moment in terms of understanding what's changed about the nature of globalization that we've all grown up with.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: China's factories are famous for making cheap t- shirts and jeans.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In the 1990s and 2000s, China was the factory of the world, thanks to his endless supply of cheap labor.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: China's centric globalization has dominated the last three decades. Clothing, shoes, 50, 60, 70, sometimes 90 percent of products made in China.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Corporate America thrived on this China centric business marvel, experiencing a golden age of profit.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We want to keep our jobs.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But American manufacturing was hit hard.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They want to take your throat out, they want to cut you apart.They're ripping us off, folks. We're gonna a stand up to China.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And along came Donald Trump, who punished China with tariffs. President Biden kept those tariffs.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: When the world's factory shuts down, it ripples around the globe.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And the pandemic disrupted supply chains with China even more. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Lined up, ready to go.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: Running out of a vast range of manufactured goods causes a significant reassessment.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: American companies wanted their suppliers to be much closer to home.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Geographical proximity to the US cannot be overstated.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And a popular trend emerged.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Nearshoring.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Nearshoring.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Nearshoring.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Nearshoring.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: Nearshoring basically means bringing production back from a faraway place to a closer place, and they look in part at Mexico.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Mexico became America's ideal partner, right across the border with low cost labor and a free trade deal. In 2023, it eclipsed China as America's leading source of foreign goodsO'NEIL: We see trade up 20, 25 percent. It's in autos, it's in machinery, it's in electronics.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: I mean, there's a feeling of you got to get in there fast. It's like almost a gold rush.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: There have been more goods coming across the border at Laredo, Texas, than goods arriving at the Port of Los Angeles.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Trucks often wait hours for a chance to cross into Laredo.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Many of those goods come from Monterrey, and its home state of Nuevo Leon.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Tesla is opening a gigafactory in the Monterey area.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The state offers good security and a highly skilled workforce. Tec de Monterrey, Mexico's MIT, trains top engineers. The competition for local labor is intense, driving unemployment down to less than 3 percent.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: The Mexican worker, they're certainly in a position where they have much greater bargaining power than in many other parts of the world.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Chinese companies are showing their robust manufacturing prisons.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And in an unexpected twist, lots of Chinese companies are coming to Mexico too, to get a made in Mexico label for their goods and avoid US tariffs. Trade between China and Mexico spiked nearly 40 percent in four years.

utterances.speaker: GOODMAN
utterances.sentences: Chinese companies are reacting aggressively.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Our hemisphere has been invaded by China.
